Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Bi-Functional Redox Materials with Facilitated Oxygen Transport for Catalytic Conditioning of Biomass-Derived Syngas

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Li, Fanxing
Proposal Number: 1254351
Institution: North Carolina State University
Title: CAREER:Bi-Functional Redox Materials with Facilitated Oxygen Transport for Catalytic Conditioning of Biomass-Derived Syngas

Biomass can be converted into electricity, hydrogen, and liquid fuels through gasification. However, the removal of tars represents a critical challenge to biomass gasification. The existing tar removal catalysts are only active for tar reforming and/or partial oxidation in the presence of an external oxidant, the redox catalyst. This project will develop a catalyst that also functions as a oxidant. The redox catalyst is composed of a primary metal oxide for oxygen storage, a mixed ionic-electronic conductor (MIEC) support for O2- transport, and a catalytically active surface for tar reforming/oxidation. The embedded oxygen can make the catalyst more active by participating in tar oxidation reactions. The catalyst will be operated under a cyclic redox mode for lattice oxygen replenishment. This project will investigate (i) lattice O2- migration in the redox catalyst and the effect of MIEC support on catalyst activity; (ii) the effect of catalyst surface on its activity and the surface reaction scheme for tar oxidation; (iii) redox catalyst optimization strategy and performance evaluations.

Intellectual Merit:
The project will devote a concerted effort towards understanding the surface reaction and O2- conduction schemes of the unique redox catalyst, which can be highly effective for tar removal. Besides acting as an active catalyst, the embedded lattice oxygen can be shuttled to the catalyst surface, by the MIEC support, for tar oxidation. The MIEC support will also increase the catalyst's sintering resistance by creating a solid-state O2- pathway even at low porosity. The lattice oxygen can also increase the catalyst lifetime by retarding coke formation and sulfur poisoning. The research will provide essential guidance on redox catalyst design and optimization.

Broader Impact:
Development of an effective and robust tar removal catalyst can be a key enabling step for the deployment of gasification based biomass-to-liquid fuel processes. This project will provide fundamental insights for designing an optimized catalyst. The unique concept coupled with the carefully designed research plan will likely to result in a viable catalyst for sustainable biomass conversion through gasification. The PI will also integrate his research with education. To inspire K12 students' interest in STEM and sustainable energy, the PI will develop and present an interactive module named "Engineering Our Way out of Global Warming" to both national and international audiences. A parallel Apple/Android App, "Engineer's Toolbox for Global Warming" will also be launched in collaboration with NC State Computer Science Department and Argonne National Lab.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In terms of intellectual merit: We have successfully achieved the primary goal of the proposed project in terms of developing a unique family of redox catalysts that are both catalytically active for biomass tar removal and effective for lattice oxygen storage and donation. The redox catalyst, when operated under a cyclic redox mode, can effectively convert tar in biomass derived syngas. In terms of redox catalyst development, we designed mixed ionic-electronic conductor enhanced, iron oxide based redox catalysts in either composite or core-shell forms. The resulting redox catalysts were shown to be two orders of magnitude more active for methane conversion, when compared to state-of-the-art oxide based redox catalysts/oxygen carriers at the time (2014). We also investigated strategies to enhance the surface catalytic activity of the redox catalysts and were able to further improve the activity of the redox catalysts. As a result, the onset temperature for tar model compound conversion was decreased by more than 200 celsius. 

These advancements in redox catalyst design and optimization were realized through fundamental understanding of (a) the bulk lattice O2- migration pathways in the redox catalyst and the rate limiting step for redox reactions; (b) the effect of catalyst surface on its activity and the surface reaction scheme for tar model compound oxidation. Based on these fundamental understandings, we have developed rationalized approaches for redox catalyst optimization. Moreover, the findings have resulted in materials and applications beyond tar removal. For instance, we have developed materials that are highly effective for CO2 splitting with more than 98% single pass conversion. We have also reported materials and redox schemes for effective H2O splitting to produce hydrogen. Resulting from these exciting scientific findings, we have published 15 journal articles, including two well-received perspective articles, in high impact journals such as Science Advances, Energy and Environmental Science, and ACS Catalysis.

In terms of broader impacts: Our research findings are directly related to sustainable energy conversion and emission reductions. For instance, the redox catalysts can effectively convert tar in biomass derived syngas, a major challenge to biomass utilization. The findings from the project can promote the usage of domestic and renewable biomass. Moreover, our findings on the effective approaches for CO2 splitting can convert CO2, a greenhouse gas, into value added CO, an important chemical feedstock. Two patent applications were filed resulting from the project. One of them was licensed to a start-up company for potential implementations. Our research findings were also reported in a number of media outlets. I and my students have communicated our research findings through more than 30 invited and contributed presentations.

The project also offered extensive opportunities for student training. Multiple Ph.D. students and postdocs were involved in this project. Moreover, we hosted more than 10 undergraduate researchers and high school students for energy and sustainability research. Three undergraduate researchers co-authored journal articles. The three batches of high school students (6 students total) we hosted all participated in the Siemens Competition and were awarded National Semifinalists. 


Last Modified: 05/12/2019
Modified by: Fanxing Li

Image
  • The proposed project investigated a novel redox catalyst (RC) for tar removal from biomass gasifier. The process, as illustrated in the figure, involves cyclic reduction-regeneration of the RC particles.
    Fanxing Li
    Copyrighted
    Fanxing Li
    A cyclic redox scheme for biomass tar removal
